column1: Black women and pregnancy: High blood pressure
column3: What does it mean to have high blood pressure?Blood pressure is the force exerted by the blood pushing against the artery walls. When the pressure in the arteries becomes too high, it's called high blood pressure, or hypertension.A blood pressure reading is given as two numbers. The first number represents the pressure created when your heart beats (systolic pressure); the second number is the pressure when the heart is at rest between beats (diastolic pressure). High blood pressure is defined as a reading of 140/90 or higher, even if just one of the numbers is higher.Most pregnant women with high blood pressure have healthy babies, but a few have problems. High blood pressure problems occur in 6 percent to 8 percent of all pregnancies in the United States. The complications may be mild or severe, and can include preterm labor and low birth weight.African American women are more likely than other women to have high blood pressure, but any woman of any race can have it.What are the different types of high blood pressure?There are four types of high blood pressure that can affect pregnant women:Chronic hypertension: This is ongoing high blood pressure that's diagnosed before pregnancy or before the 20th week of pregnancy. If a woman is diagnosed with gestational hypertension (starting after 20 weeks) and her blood pressure is still high 12 weeks after delivery, the condition is also considered chronic. Read more about chronic hypertension during pregnancy.Gestational hypertension: This form of high blood pressure develops after 20 weeks of pregnancy and goes away after delivery. Read more about gestational hypertension.Preeclampsia: This is a serious disorder that occurs when a pregnant woman has high blood pressure and protein in her urine after 20 weeks of pregnancy. Untreated preeclampsia can cause serious complications to mother and baby that could become fatal. Preeclampsia affects 3 to 8 percent of pregnant women, and it's even more common among African Americans. Chronic and gestational hypertension are risk factors for preeclampsia. Read more about preeclampsia.Chronic hypertension with preeclampsia: As many as 1 in 4 women with chronic hypertension and half of women with severe chronic hypertension (180/110 or higher) also develop preeclampsia during pregnancy.Why is it especially important for black women to know about high blood pressure and preeclampsia?High blood pressure, often called simply "pressure" in the black community, is more common among black women than in the general population. In the United States, 45 percent of non-Hispanic black females age 20 and older have high blood pressure, compared with 27 percent of non-Hispanic white women. What's more, African American women have an 85 percent higher rate of medical visits for high blood pressure than Caucasian women.It's unclear why high blood pressure is more common in black women than in women of other racial groups in the United States. Some studies link high levels of hypertension among black women to physical inactivity. For non-Hispanic black females age 18 and older, 33.9 percent are inactive, compared with 21.6 percent of non-Hispanic white females.Preeclampsia is also more prevalent in black women, although exactly how much more common it is in African Americans than in Caucasians isn't known. Also, the disorder is likely to be more severe and show up earlier in black women, when they are 6 months pregnant, while it typically develops in white women when they are 7 to 8 months pregnant.Medical professionals don't know why black women are more likely to develop preeclampsia, but they suspect that it's related to the higher rates of hypertension. Also, one study found that black women had less folic acid and more of a certain amino acid than white women. The study suggested that black women might benefit from taking more folic acid during pregnancy. What causes high blood pressure?In most cases of high blood pressure, there's no identifiable cause. This is called essential hypertension or primary hypertension.Studies show that a number of factors can raise a woman's risk of primary high blood pressure. In the United States, blacks are twice as likely as whites to have high blood pressure, although the gap begins to narrow around age 44. After age 65, black women have a higher rate of high blood pressure than any other group of people.You're also more likely to develop high blood pressure if you have a family history of the disease, and your risk increases as you age.Other risk factors include smoking, stress, obesity, alcohol abuse, a diet high in fat or salt, low potassium intake, lack of physical activity, and certain chronic conditions such as diabetes and high cholesterol.About 5 to 10 percent of cases of high blood pressure are due to underlying conditions such as kidney abnormalities, tumors of the adrenal gland, congenital heart defects, and certain medications such as birth control pills, cold remedies, and decongestants. This type of high blood pressure, called secondary hypertension, tends to appear suddenly and cause higher blood pressure than primary hypertension.What causes preeclampsia?Researchers have learned a lot about preeclampsia in the last decade, but many aspects of the condition remain a mystery. Experts believe that placental abnormalities, genetics, nutrition, certain underlying diseases, and the way your immune system reacts to pregnancy may play a role.Studies also show that these risk factors make it more likely that a woman will develop preeclampsia:Past personal history of preeclampsiaFirst pregnancyFamily history of preeclampsiaPast personal history of chronic high blood pressure, kidney disease, diabetes, certain thrombophilias (blood-clotting disorders), systemic lupus erythematosus, and other autoimmune disordersMultiple pregnancy (carrying two or more babies)Age younger than 20 years or older than 35African AmericanObesity (body mass index of 30 or more)For more information, see our article on preeclampsia.What are the symptoms of preeclampsia and other types of high blood pressure?If you have mild preeclampsia and other forms of high blood pressure, you might not have any symptoms. But more severe cases may be accompanied by the following:Severe or persistent headacheVision changes, including double vision, blurred vision, seeing spots of flashing light, sensitivity to light, or temporary loss of visionDizzinessIntense pain or tenderness in your upper abdomenWeight gain of more than 4 pounds per weekSudden swelling in your face or puffiness around your eyes, more than slight swelling of your hands, or excessive or sudden swelling of your feet or anklesNausea and vomiting (other than morning sickness in early pregnancy)Call your caregiver immediately if you have any of these warning signs.Some symptoms, such as swelling and weight gain, may seem like normal pregnancy complaints, so you might not know you have the condition until it's discovered at a routine prenatal visit. This is one of the reasons it's so important not to miss your appointments. What are the risks if I have high blood pressure or preeclampsia during pregnancy?A pregnant woman with severe preeclampsia or severe hypertension is at risk for congestive heart failure, seizures, kidney or liver problems, vision changes, and stroke. Some studies have shown that women over 40 who have had hypertension for 15 or more years are the most likely to have these problems.All forms of high blood pressure can cause complications during pregnancy and birth. Those include:Low birth weight High blood pressure can cause the blood vessels to constrict and decrease in the uterus, which will affect the supply of oxygen and nutrients to the baby.Placental abruption When the placenta partially or completely peels away from the uterine wall before delivery, it can deprive the baby of oxygen and nutrients and cause heavy bleeding in the mother. Untreated abruption is dangerous for both mother and child.Preterm delivery Some women with severe high blood pressure or preeclampsia require an early delivery to prevent potentially life-threatening complications to the mother and child.The risk for these complications is highest for women with severe chronic hypertension accompanied by preeclampsia. And having chronic hypertension significantly increases your risk of developing preeclampsia. As many as 1 in 4 women with chronic hypertension and half of women with severe chronic hypertension will develop preeclampsia during pregnancy.How is high blood pressure monitored and managed during pregnancy?With close observation and careful management, most women with chronic or gestational hypertension have healthy pregnancies.At every prenatal appointment, a caregiver will take your blood pressure by wrapping an inflatable cuff around your upper arm. Your urine will be checked for excess protein to determine whether you have preeclampsia.Ultrasounds and fetal heart rate testing are usually done repeatedly to measure your baby's well-being. Your provider may refer you to a high-risk pregnancy specialist, called a perinatologist.It's important to go to all of your prenatal appointments because hypertension can get significantly worse during pregnancy and cause serious problems for you and your baby. But also keep in mind that blood pressure often becomes somewhat lower on its own during the second trimester, says Andrea Jackson, an ob-gyn at the Physician & Midwife Collaborative in Alexandria, Virginia. "This is not a sign to lose vigilance, because it typically goes back up in the third trimester," she says.If you have chronic high blood pressure, it's a good idea to see your healthcare provider before you try to conceive. A preconception appointment allows your provider to ensure that your blood pressure is under control and to evaluate any medication you're taking.While some medications are considered safe during pregnancy, others  such as ACE inhibitors  should not be taken during pregnancy.It's important to take prescription medication according to the instructions you're given. Don't stop taking it or adjust the dosage without your caregiver's consent.If you have mild hypertension, your provider may advise you to stop taking your medication or reduce the dose. If it's severe, you'll probably need to take medication throughout your pregnancy.If at any time during pregnancy, your blood pressure gets too high, you'll be hospitalized until it's under control.For more information, see our articles on chronic hypertension and gestational hypertension. Can I have a regular delivery if I have high blood pressure?You and your healthcare provider will discuss how and when you should deliver your baby. Women with mild high blood pressure typically have regular deliveries.If you have severe high blood pressure, your provider may suggest that you deliver a few weeks before your due date to prevent complications. He'll determine whether it's better for you to have a c-section or to be induced and attempt to deliver vaginally.How is preeclampsia managed during pregnancy?It depends on how severe the preeclampsia is, how far along you are, and how your baby's doing. You'll probably be hospitalized for an initial assessment  and possibly for the rest of your pregnancy.Mild preeclampsia: If your condition is mild, expect to visit your provider a few times a week. Your baby's well-being will be monitored with tests, such as ultrasounds and fetal heart rate screenings.You'll get regular urine and blood tests to see whether the preeclampsia is progressing and harming your health. Your provider might recommend that you reduce your activity.If the preeclampsia develops several weeks before your due date, your provider may recommend bedrest to lower your blood pressure and increase blood flow to your placenta, which gives your baby time to mature. There's no standard definition of bedrest, so make sure you understand how much activity is allowed.Your provider also may prescribe an antihypertensive to lower your blood pressure until delivery.At 37 weeks or more, you'll likely be induced, especially if your cervix is starting to thin out and dilate. If there are signs that you or your baby won't be able to tolerate labor, you'll have a c-section.Severe preeclampsia: Expectant moms with severe preeclampsia are almost always hospitalized. In the hospital their baby's health and the amniotic fluid level is monitored through fetal heart testing and ultrasounds. (Low amniotic fluid indicates poor blood supply to the baby.)If you're at 34 weeks or more, you'll be induced or, in certain situations, delivered by c-section. If you're at less than 34 weeks, you'll be given corticosteroids to help your baby's lungs mature more quickly. If you don't deliver immediately, both you and your baby will be monitored very closely.Most moms with severe preeclampsia spend the remainder of their pregnancy in the hospital, and are often cared for by a high-risk pregnancy specialist, called a perinatologist.Read our complete preeclampsia article for more information.What is HELLP syndrome?About 20 percent of women with severe preeclampsia also develop a disorder called HELLP syndrome. The name is an acronym for hemolysis, the breakdown of red blood cells; elevated liver enzymes; and low platelets, the blood cells that are necessary for clotting.Symptoms may include nausea and vomiting, headache, upper abdominal pain and general malaise. Women with HELLP syndrome can develop these symptoms during pregnancy or in the first 48 hours after delivery. They're treated with medications to control blood pressure and prevent seizures, and sometimes with blood transfusions. If still pregnant, they almost always require early delivery to prevent serious complications.If you develop preeclampsia, you'll have your blood tested periodically for signs of HELLP syndrome.Some U.S. studies have found that, for unknown reasons, HELLP is less common in African Americans than in Caucasians. What is eclampsia?Infrequently, preeclampsia can lead to seizures, a condition called eclampsia. "Pre-eclampsia" is so named because it's the condition that precedes these seizures. Eclampsia can have very serious consequences for both the mother and the baby.Sometimes, the seizures occur without warning. For this reason, all women with severe preeclampsia and many women with mild preeclampsia are given magnesium sulfate, an antiseizure medication.The seizures may also be preceded by symptoms such as severe or persistent headache, vision changes (blurred vision, seeing spots, or sensitivity to light, for example), mental confusion, or intense upper abdominal pain.Some U.S. studies have found that, for unknown reasons, eclampsia is more common in African Americans than in Caucasians.Can I have a regular delivery if I have preeclampsia?If you have preeclampsia, your doctor or midwife will monitor you closely in the third trimester. If you have severe preeclampsia, your provider may want your baby to be delivered early  at 34 weeks or later. You'll be induced or have a c-section at the first sign that the preeclampsia is getting worse or your baby is not thriving.What can I do to prevent complications if I have high blood pressure during pregnancy?"You have to keep your blood pressure under control during pregnancy," says Gail Jackson, an ob-gyn with a private practice in the Cedars Sinai Medical Towers in Beverly Hills. "The best way to accomplish that is by taking care of yourself." Here are some tips:Before becoming pregnantTalk to your healthcare provider. If you have high blood pressure, it's important to schedule a preconception appointment with the provider who'll be handing your pregnancy. Your doctor or midwife will evaluate how well you're managing your high blood pressure and consider any treatment changes you may need to make before getting pregnant. If you take medication, your provider might tell you to change the dose or the type of medicine. Some are safe, but others such as ACE inhibitors  may raise the risk of birth defects when taken during pregnancy.Lead a healthy lifestyle. Most providers will want to make sure your blood pressure is under control before you get pregnant. If it's not, your doctor or midwife will probably suggest that you make some lifestyle changes such as limiting salt intake, exercising, and losing weight.During pregnancyEat healthy. Geddis Abel-Bey, an ob-gyn with a private practice in Queens, recommends seeing a nutritionist. "The things that led you to have high blood pressure are probably diet-related. I can tell you to throw the salt shaker out the window and put the smoked meats away, but I can't follow you home. You have to learn to eat better for you, your baby, and hopefully for your lifetime," he says.Get plenty of rest. Reduce stress and limit work hours. Take naps if you can. Prepare yourself for the strong possibility of being on bedrest in the third trimester, especially if you develop preeclampsia.Take your medicine. The good news is that many blood pressure medications have been in use for 30 years and have been proved safe and effective during pregnancy. Take your medication exactly as prescribed.Watch your weight. It's important to gain enough weight to support your baby's growth, but putting on too much weight can put additional stress on your heart.Avoid smoking and alcohol. If you smoke or drink, it's now more important than ever to stop.Go to your prenatal appointments. Start prenatal care early and continue it through the pregnancy. This allows your healthcare provider to find and treat conditions such as preeclampsia early.Is there any way to avoid getting preeclampsia?No one knows for sure how to prevent preeclampsia, although there's a lot of research going on in this area. A number of studies have looked into whether taking extra calcium, vitamins, folic acid, or a low dose of aspirin can help.Read more about preeclampsia.What will happen after the birth?If you have gestational hypertension or mild preeclampsia, delivery is the only cure. Blood pressure usually returns to normal after the birth. If not, your provider may prescribe medication.Women with severe preeclampsia usually remain under close supervision for a few days after giving birth. Your caregiver will keep tabs on your blood pressure and watch for signs of other complications. Many cases of eclampsia and HELLP syndrome happen after delivery, usually within 48 hours.If you have chronic hypertension, you may still be at risk for some complications as your cardiovascular system readjusts after delivery. You will likely be monitored closely for at least 48 hours after birth and may have your blood pressure medication dosage adjusted.It is possible to develop preeclampsia after delivery, so let your provider know if you develop any symptoms, even after you return home.Women who have high blood pressure and preeclampsia are encouraged to breastfeed, even if they're taking medication. Your provider can prescribe medications that are safe for your breastfeeding baby.

column1: Hispanic women and pregnancy: Gestational diabetes
column3: What is gestational diabetes?Gestational diabetes is a type of diabetes that some women get during pregnancy. Between 2 and 10 percent of expectant mothers develop this condition, making it one of the most common health problems of pregnancy. (The rate is even higher among Latinas.)Diabetes is complicated, but in a nutshell it means you have abnormally high levels of sugar in your blood. Here's what happens:When you eat, your digestive system breaks most of your food down into a type of sugar called glucose. The glucose enters your bloodstream and then, with the help of insulin (a hormone made by your pancreas), your cells use the glucose as fuel. However, if your body doesn't produce enough insulin  or your cells have a problem responding to the insulin  too much glucose remains in your blood instead of moving into the cells and getting converted to energy.When you're pregnant, hormonal changes can make your cells less responsive to insulin. For most moms-to-be, this isn't a problem: When the body needs additional insulin, the pancreas dutifully secretes more of it. But if your pancreas can't keep up with the increased insulin demand during pregnancy, your blood glucose levels rise too high, resulting in gestational diabetes.Most women with gestational diabetes don't continue to have the condition after their baby is born. Once you've had gestational diabetes, though, you're more likely to get it during a future pregnancy and to develop diabetes later in life.Why do Hispanic women need to know about gestational diabetes?Gestational diabetes disproportionately affects pregnant Latinas. In fact, Latinas have a greater predisposition to all types of diabetes, and 1 in 4 has some form of the disease. Latinas have a 52.5 percent risk of developing diabetes in their lifetime. The risk for Caucasian women is slightly higher than 31 percent.The genetic predisposition for diabetes puts Latinas at higher risk of developing gestational diabetes. This is especially true because, in many cases, Latinas don't even know they have diabetes when they get pregnant.Overall, more than 11 percent of the Hispanic population has diabetes, but the disease affects certain groups more than others. Puerto Ricans, for example, have the highest rates of diagnosed diabetes with 12.6 percent, followed by Mexican Americans with 11.9 percent and Cubans with 8.2 percent.Something else to keep in mind is that diabetes in all its forms tends to affect Hispanics at younger ages than it does other races and ethnic populations. With more Latinas giving birth in the United States at younger ages than other women, it's important to check with your doctor before planning a family.How will I know if I have gestational diabetes?Gestational diabetes usually has no symptoms. That's why almost all pregnant women have a glucose screening test between 24 and 28 weeks.However, if you're at high risk for diabetes (as Latinas generally are) or are showing signs of it (such as having sugar in your urine), your healthcare provider will recommend this screening test at your first prenatal visit and then repeat the test at 24 to 28 weeks if the initial result is negative.If you do show a positive result on a glucose screening test, it doesn't necessarily mean that you have gestational diabetes. But it does mean that you'll need to take a longer follow-up test (a glucose tolerance test, or GTT) to find out for sure. How can I tell whether I'm at high risk for gestational diabetes?As a Hispanic  or a member of any other ethnic group with a high incidence of diabetes  you're considered to be at high risk for gestational diabetes. In addition, according to the American Diabetes Association, you're at high risk (and should be screened early) if:You're obese (your body mass index is over 30).You've had gestational diabetes in a previous pregnancy.You have sugar in your urine.You have a strong family history of diabetes.More than 76 percent of Latinas in the United States are overweight, with 45 percent of them considered obese. That plus the fact that Latinas have a genetic predisposition to diabetes are two powerful reasons to get checked for the disease.Some healthcare providers will also screen you early if you have other risk factors, such as:You've previously given birth to a big baby. Some use 8 pounds, 13 ounces as the cutoff; others use 9 pounds, 14 ounces.You've had an unexplained stillbirth.You've had a baby with a birth defect.You have high blood pressure.You're 35 or older.In addition, a study published in the March 2010 issue of Obstetrics & Gynecology found an association between excessive weight gain during pregnancy  particularly in the first trimester  and the risk of gestational diabetes. Researchers found the risk highest in women who were overweight to begin with and in nonwhite women.Keep in mind that many women who develop gestational diabetes don't have any risk factors. That's why most providers order the screening at 24 to 28 weeks for all their pregnant patients.How does having gestational diabetes affect my pregnancy?Most women who develop diabetes during pregnancy go on to have healthy babies. Dietary changes and exercise may be enough to keep your blood sugar levels under control. Sometimes medication is needed, too.Latinas who have diabetes are vulnerable to many more risks. To protect yourself, you must be vigilant about prevention, symptoms, and medical supervision.How does having gestational diabetes affect my baby in utero?Poorly controlled diabetes can have serious short- and long-term consequences for your baby.If your blood sugar levels are too high, too much glucose ends up in your baby's blood. Your baby's pancreas then has to produce more insulin to process it. All that excess blood sugar and insulin can cause your baby to put on extra weight while still in utero, particularly in the upper body.This can lead to what's called macrosomia. A macrosomic baby may be too large to enter the birth canal. Or the baby's head may enter the canal but then his shoulders may get stuck. In this situation, called shoulder dystocia, your doctor or midwife has to use special maneuvers to deliver your baby.Delivery sometimes results in a fractured bone or nerve damage. Both of these heal without permanent problems in nearly 99 percent of babies. (In very rare cases, the baby suffers brain damage from lack of oxygen.)The maneuvers needed to deliver a broad-shouldered baby can also lead to injuries to the vaginal area or require a large episiotomy for you.Because of these risks, if it looks like your baby may be overly large, your healthcare provider may recommend that you give birth by cesarean section. Fortunately, only a minority of women with well-controlled gestational diabetes end up with overly large babies.Some studies have found a link between severe gestational diabetes and an increased risk of stillbirth in the last two months of pregnancy. Women with gestational diabetes are also more likely to develop preeclampsia, especially if they were obese before pregnancy or if their blood sugar levels aren't well controlled. How does having gestational diabetes affect my baby after birth?Babies who have excessive fat stores as a result of high maternal sugar levels during pregnancy often continue to be overweight in childhood and adulthood.Shortly after birth, your baby may have low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) because his body is still producing extra insulin in response to your excess glucose. This is much more likely if your blood sugar levels were high during pregnancy and especially if they were high during labor.Your delivery team will test your baby's blood sugar at birth and continue to check it as needed by taking a drop of blood from his heel. Feeding your baby as soon as possible after birth, preferably by breastfeeding, can help prevent or correct hypoglycemia.In severe cases of hypoglycemia, though, your baby will receive an IV glucose solution. Testing your newborn's blood sugar and providing an IV if necessary can prevent serious problems such as seizures, coma, and brain damage.Your baby may also be at higher risk for breathing problems at birth, particularly if your blood sugar levels aren't well controlled or you deliver early. (The lungs of babies whose mothers have diabetes tend to mature a bit later.) The risk of newborn jaundice goes up, too.If your blood sugar control is especially poor, your baby is at risk for polycythemia (an increase in the number of red cells in the blood) and hypocalcemia (low calcium in the blood), and your baby's heart function could be affected.What will I need to do if I have gestational diabetes?You'll need to keep diligent track of your glucose levels while you're pregnant, using a home glucose meter or strips. To keep those levels where they should be, you'll be advised to:Eat a well-planned diet. The American Diabetes Association recommends getting nutritional counseling from a registered dietitian. The dietitian can help you develop specific meal and snack plans based on your height, weight, and activity level.Your diet must have the correct balance of protein, fats, and carbohydrates, while providing the proper vitamins, minerals, and calories. To keep your glucose levels stable, it's very important that you don't skip meals, especially breakfast, and that you avoid sugary items like candy, cookies, cakes, and soda.You also need to stay away from simple carbohydrates, such as white-flour tortillas and white bread. These are digested easily and pass quickly into the bloodstream, raising your glucose levels immediately. It's best to eat whole-grain and corn tortillas and whole-grain bread. These complex carbohydrates take longer to digest, calling for lower levels of insulin to handle the glucose that enters the blood.This may sound daunting, but it's not so hard once you get the hang of it.Don't think of yourself as being on a special or restrictive diet. The principles of the diabetes diet are good ones for everyone to follow. Think of this as an opportunity to create healthier eating habits for yourself and your whole family. If everyone in the house is eating the same foods, you won't feel as deprived.Exercise. Studies show that moderate exercise helps improve your body's ability to process glucose, keeping blood sugar levels in check. Many women with gestational diabetes benefit from 30 minutes of daily aerobic activity, such as walking or swimming. Ask your healthcare provider what level of physical activity would be beneficial for you.Take insulin if necessary. If you're unable to control your blood sugar well enough with diet and exercise alone, your provider will prescribe insulin shots for you to give yourself. About 15 percent of women with gestational diabetes need insulin. Recently, some providers have been prescribing oral medications instead of injections for some cases of gestational diabetes.Will I need additional testing while I'm pregnant?Your healthcare provider may want to monitor your baby more intensively during your last two to three months of pregnancy, depending on the severity of your diabetes and whether you have any other medical or obstetrical problems.More prenatal visits and testingThis will probably mean that you'll have more frequent prenatal visits than you normally would. You'll need to start counting your baby's movements at 28 weeks so you can alert your provider immediately if you sense that your baby is less active.If you can't keep your blood sugar under control or it's high enough that you need medication, or if you have any other risk factors, you'll probably be tested to check on your baby's well-being beginning at about 32 weeks (and possibly as early as 28 weeks, depending on your individual situation).This testing may include fetal heart monitoring (nonstress tests) and periodic ultrasound tests called biophysical profiles. If you have mild gestational diabetes kept well under control without medication and you have no other problems, you probably won't begin these tests until about 36 weeks or possibly later.More ultrasoundsYou may also have one or more ultrasounds during the third trimester to monitor your baby's growth. Your provider may order one in the early part of the third trimester to help assess your need for medication.You'll probably have an ultrasound close to your due date, too. If your baby seems to be getting very big, your delivery might be induced before your due date, or your provider may recommend delivering by c-section.Note: If your diabetes was diagnosed in the first half of your pregnancy, it's more likely that you had unrecognized diabetes before you conceived. In this case, your provider may order a fetal echocardiogram (an ultrasound that focuses on your baby's heart). The risk of birth defects, especially heart defects, is higher if your blood sugar was high during the first eight weeks of pregnancy, when your baby's body was being formed. Will I continue to have diabetes after my baby is born?Most women with gestational diabetes don't remain diabetic after giving birth. But you will be more likely to develop gestational diabetes again during your next pregnancy.Latina moms who have had gestational diabetes are also more likely to develop type 2 diabetes in the five to ten years after their pregnancy. According to one study, each year after the pregnancy in which they had gestational diabetes, 12 percent of Mexican American women developed type 2 diabetes.As many as a third of women who've had gestational diabetes will continue to have either diabetes or what's known as impaired glucose tolerance. That means their glucose levels are higher than normal, but not as high as they would be with diabetes.For this reason, you'll need to have a glucose test about six to 12 weeks after delivery. This test requires fasting overnight and can be done at your six-week postpartum doctor visit.For moms who had gestational diabetes and have a normal postpartum screening, the American Diabetes Association recommends repeat testing at least every three years.Does having gestational diabetes put me at higher risk for diabetes in the future?Yes. About one-third to one-half of women who have gestational diabetes will have it again in a later pregnancy. And up to 50 percent of women with gestational diabetes will develop diabetes at some point in the future. Your risk is highest if any of the following apply to you:You're obese. (Your risk is 50 to 75 percent if you're obese and less than 25 percent if you're at a normal weight.)You had very high blood sugar levels during pregnancy (especially if you needed medication).Your gestational diabetes was diagnosed early in pregnancy.The results of your postpartum glucose test were borderline (relatively high, but not high enough to classify you as a diabetic).What can I do to minimize my risk of developing diabetes in the future?Keeping your weight down, making healthy food choices, and exercising regularly can help ward off the disease.In addition, breastfeeding your baby may provide you with some protection. There's research suggesting an association between breastfeeding and higher postpartum weight loss, as well as a lower risk of developing type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease.For Latinas, developing a support system also helps. Work on learning and sharing what you find out about diabetes, healthy foods to eat, and activities you can do with others. Research shows that what's most helpful for Latinas is a sense of support from people who care about your getting better and managing your condition.What can I do to minimize related risks for my child through infancy and beyond?It starts during pregnancy. Do your best to keep your blood sugar levels in check while your baby is in utero. (See "What will I need to do if I have gestational diabetes?")After birth, nurse your baby. There's evidence that breastfeeding has a positive effect on glucose metabolism and may help prevent childhood obesity and reduce your child's risk of diabetes, among other things.Your child is at higher risk for childhood and adult obesity, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. So it's particularly important that you help him eat a healthy diet, maintain a normal weight, and stay physically active.Finally, be sure your child's healthcare provider knows that you had diabetes during pregnancy.Show sources Hide sources ACOG. 2001 (reaffirmed 2008).
